title: Socrates' Defense at His Trial
description: A fast breakdown of Socrates' Defense at His Trial for builders.

hook.text: In 399 BCE, Athens put Socrates on trial for corrupting the youth. He used the trial to teach one last lesson.

buildup.text: Instead of begging for mercy, Socrates argued that questioning authority was his duty to the city.

discovery.text: He compared himself to a gadfly â€” an annoying insect that keeps a lazy horse alert and moving.

twist.text: The jury convicted him anyway. Socrates chose death over exile, saying an unexamined life isn't worth living.

climax.text: His defense became philosophy's founding document â€” the idea that truth matters more than survival.

punchline.text: He lost the trial. He won the argument forever.

quiz.question: What metaphor did Socrates use to describe his role in Athens?
options: A gadfly that keeps a lazy horse alert
